Graphical abstract Hydrocarbons, including polyethylene, can be depolymerized into linear alkanes at temperatures ≤ 220°C, using a tandem heterogeneous palladium and rhenium oxide catalyst system with novel synergy. Recent proposed approaches in the depolymerization of waste plastics employ an olefin intermediate to produce alkanes or alkenes using olefin metathesis in tandem chemistry. Here we investigated the role of the dehydrogenation catalyst on reaction rate, kinetics, and product distribution in heterogeneous tandem dehydrogenation and olefin metathesis (alkane metathesis) of three different alkane reactants, including polyethylene. We found that many properties to which alkane dehydrogenation rates were sensitive—including metal composition, nanoparticle size, and surface doping of Re species also controlled activity in Tandem D/OM. When comparing Pd, Pt, and Pt3Sn1, supported Pd in tandem with a Re2O7 olefin metathesis catalyst showed four-fold higher activity (surface area basis) compared to Pt or Pt3Sn1 catalysts on the same support, mainly due to differences in the rate of hydrogenation. Catalyst preparation resulted in metal nanoparticles partially covered by ReOx, as seen from elemental mapping. Co-location of Re2O7 and Pd correlated with increased rates of hydrogenation (i.e., an increase in the rate of alkane formation and simultaneous lowering of the rate of alkene formation), with a reaction order in catalyst study that further supported this conclusion. The Pd and Re2O7 system displayed marked improvement compared to Pt or Pt3Sn1 with Re2O7, and previous work, in the depolymerization rate of a linear polyethylene feedstock, with over 94 % reduction in polymer molecular weight in 15 h at 190 °C using less catalyst and increased reactant loadings, while keeping solvent to polymer consumption below 2.5. Keywords Dehydrogenation Olefin metathesis Alkane metathesis Plastics upcycling Tandem catalysis 1 Introduction The rapid accumulation of plastic waste in landfills, waterways, and our oceans is resulting in a poorly understood environmental crisis, which current recycling technologies are not capable of ameliorating. Only 9 % of plastics have been recycled over the last seven decades [1], and the use of plastics is expected to continue growing through 2050; there has never been a greater need to develop technologies that can valorize waste plastics and incentivize the reclamation of this recalcitrant waste. A wealth of recent innovations have focused on the use of hydrocracking [2–7] or hydrogenolysis [8–14] to depolymerize polyolefin plastics like polyethylene to linear alkane products [8,9], which have even been described as high quality lubricants [8]. However, the use of hydrogen entails the need for abundant hydrogen feedstocks, preferably not derived from carbon sources (i.e. gray hydrogen15). Unfortunately, the vast majority of current hydrogen production processes in chemical refining are from fossil sources, mainly steam reforming of methane, but also naphtha and coal [15,16]. The carbon emissions associated with gray-hydrogen production are estimated to be 9 kg CO2eq per 1 kg of H2 [15,17]. Thus, identifying plastic conversion technologies that can result in similar product distributions and chemical functionalities, while being hydrogen free are desirable [16]. Alkane metathesis, via tandem dehydrogenation and olefin metathesis or other methods, provides the opportunity to depolymerize polyolefin plastics using alkane co-reactants, akin to an alkane version of hydrogenolysis or ‘alkane-olysis,’ allowing for the selective depolymerization of plastics or other heavy hydrocarbons to linear alkanes, with inexpensive, abundant, and hydrogen-free hydrocarbon feedstocks, like n-pentane [18],n-octane [19], petroleum ethers [19], and n-decane [20], and likely more. Recent approaches have also highlighted process configurations and reaction engineering approaches to produce alkenes like propylene from polyolefins using similar tandem or cascade reaction schemes (i.e., ethenolysis) with olefin co-reactants, which provide for products that contribute more directly to a circular economy [21,22]. Alkane metathesis via tandem dehydrogenation and olefin metathesis (Scheme 1 ), first gained wide-scale attention in 2006 [23] and has seen a series of innovations, traditionally with the use of homogeneous catalyst systems, tethered systems, or grafted single sites [23–26]. However, in 2016 a study by Jia et al. [19] demonstrated the use of an organometallic iridium pincer (both surface-tethered or free), a dehydrogenation catalyst, in combination with alumina supported rhenium oxide as an olefin metathesis catalyst, capable of depolymerizing polyethylene feedstocks in approximately four days at 175 °C [19]. Alkane metathesis of PE was further investigated with a fully heterogeneous catalyst system (without tethered organometallic catalysts), which reduced reaction times to ∼ 15 h at 200 °C, using a supported Sn1Pt1 and Re2O7 catalyst system [18]. It has also been demonstrated that a system of supported Pt and a W-based olefin metathesis catalyst could fully depolymerize a PE feedstock in less than 3 h [20], though showed relatively poor reactant selectivity with up to 10-fold higher consumption of the co-reactant (i.e., solvent) compared to the starting feedstock (mass basis). Reaction conditions and results for the catalytic depolymerization of PE feedstocks (HDPE or LDPE) using alkane metathesis [18–20] are summarized in Table 1 . This is not a comprehensive review of ‘traditional’ heterogenous catalyst systems for alkane metathesis, since industrial researchers have demonstrated earlier versions with non-polymeric alkane feedstocks. [27,28]. In this work, we hypothesized that dehydrogenation is the limiting reaction in alkane metathesis, since previous groups have postulated similar effects [20,24], without a direct investigation of the effect of Pt-group dehydrogenation catalysts on overall activity in this tandem system. We sought to test whether the supported metal dehydrogenation catalyst was limiting and identify any effects on reaction rate and selectivity for both model compounds and polyethylene feedstocks. Structure property relationships for heterogeneous non-oxidative dehydrogenation catalysts have been thoroughly investigated and are in good agreement that some of the most active pure metals or bimetallic catalysts are Pt-based [29–31]. Despite the favorable intrinsic activity of Pt catalysts for alkane dehydrogenation, overall activity is often governed by coke formation [32,33], sintering [32,33], and reaction selectivity [32,33]. Sn-doping of Pt catalysts is commonly used to increase overall activity [30,31] where an atomic ratio of 3:1Pt to Sn is found to have the best activity for alkane dehydrogenation, including propane to propylene, due to several different effects of Sn promotion [30]. Other metals are known to be active for alkane dehydrogenation, including Pd, Ru, Ni, and Co, often deposited on silica (SiO2) or alumina (γ-Al2O3) supports [31]. In this work, we compared the effects of a series of alkane dehydrogenation catalysts in alkane metathesis, studying the effect of metal identity (M/γ-Al2O3) and weight loading, when coupled with a Re-based olefin metathesis catalyst (Re2O7/γ-Al2O3). 2 Results & discussion 2.1 Reaction performance: effect of dehydrogenation catalyst on tandem dehydrogenation & olefin metathesis of n-eicosane in n-pentane Dehydrogenation (Pt, Pt3Sn, Sn1Pt1, Pd, Ru, Ni, and Co) and olefin metathesis (Re2O7) catalysts were synthesized using incipient wetness impregnation with γ-Al2O3 as the support (see Supporting Information for details, including Tables S1–S3, and Fig. S1). We assessed the performance of each of our dehydrogenation catalysts in the liquid-phase alkane cross metathesis, or molecular redistribution [28], of 5 % (g/g) of n-eicosane in n-pentane at 200 °C for 15 h, where n-eicosane represents a model for polyethylene. All reactions used a physical mixture of 500 mg of a dehydrogenation catalyst in tandem with 500 mg of 10 % (g/g) Re2O7/γ-Al2O3, the heterogeneous olefin metathesis catalyst, unless otherwise stated, pretreating catalysts prior to reaction (see Supporting Information for details, including Fig. S2). The highest activity catalysts based on n-eicosane conversion are summarized in Table 2 . There are notable differences in activity for Pt3Sn, Pt, and Pd-based metal catalysts compared to the Ru, Ni, and Co-based catalysts. The Ru, Ni, and Co-based catalysts showed an n-eicosane conversion of only 12.4 % ± 4.7 %, 15.8 % ± 1.0 %, and 6.5 % ± 4.3 %, respectively, while the Pt-group metals (excluding Ru), provided n-eicosane conversions of 27.9 % ± 1.1 %, 58.9 % ± 1.5 %, and 29.3 % ± 0.7 % for 1 % Pt/γ-Al2O3, 1 % Pd/γ-Al2O3, and 1 % Pt3Sn/γ-Al2O3, respectively. This activity trend supports the conclusion that correlations of dehydrogenation activity generally govern alkane metathesis activity, since the Pt-based and Pd catalysts have much higher overall activity in this tandem chemistry. In other words, increased activity in alkane metathesis comparing Ru, Ni, and Co to Pd, Pt, and Pt3Sn is due to enhanced alkane dehydrogenation activity. 2.2 Comparison of Pt, Pt3Sn, and Pd in tandem dehydrogenation & olefin metathesis of n-eicosane The high activity, on a surface area basis of the Pd, Pt, and Pt3Sn catalysts in this tandem chemistry is not surprising considering the well-established understanding of alkane dehydrogenation activity [29–31]. Fig. 1 b shows a comparison of the product yield and conversion for the liquid-phase reaction of 5 % (g/g) n-eicosane (C20) in n-pentane at 200 °C for the three best-performing dehydrogenation catalysts, Pt, Pd, and Pt3Sn at the same catalyst weight loading of 1 % (g/g) on γ-Al2O3 in a physical mixture with 10 % Re2O7/γ-Al2O3. N-eicosane conversion was approximately double for the Pd-based catalyst compared to the Pt or the Pt3Sn, while comparing at the same mass loading of catalyst. Interestingly, CO-chemisorption (Supporting information Table S2 and H2-Chemisorption in Table S3) demonstrated metal surface areas were > 100 % higher for Pt compared with Pd, and > 50 % higher for Pt3Sn compared with Pd, suggesting that overall activity, on a surface area basis, was over 4-fold higher for Pd compared to Pt and 3-fold higher than Pt3Sn. The increase in overall alkane metathesis activity for the Pd-based catalysts compared to the Pt and Pt3Sn also was measured across all other metal loadings as well, comparing 0.4 %, 0.8 %, 1.0 %, and 2.0 % (Fig. 1a, Supporting Information Table S4, and Fig. S3). Fig. 1a shows the surface-area specific average rate of C20 disappearance across the three catalyst and four weight loadings, showing higher activity with lower weight loadings the dehydrogenation metal, with the same metathesis site population provided. Previous efforts have shown that alkane dehydrogenation activity correlates with decreasing nanoparticle size, [30–32] due to more active undercoordinated active sites (found at higher percentages of smaller nanoparticles of ∼ 3 nm diameter [34]), though suffer from decreased resistance to coking and deactivation [35]. In our study the Pt3Sn and Pd catalysts do show decreasing nanoparticle size (according to chemisorption results) with reduced weight loadings, correlating with literature trends for specific activity of alkane dehydrogenation and the activity results found here. Fig. 1c shows product selectivity when the reactions were run at the same C20 conversion, since reaction selectivities can vary as a function of reactant conversion. The mass loading of Pt/γ-Al2O3 and Pt3Sn/γ-Al2O3 in the reactor needed to be two-fold higher (four-fold higher on a surface area basis) compared to the Pd/γ-Al2O3 mass loading to obtain the same conversion. Under these conditions, product selectivity distributions for all three catalysts paired with the Re2O7/γ-Al2O3 are remarkably similar, suggesting all these catalysts are providing similar reaction pathways and not widely different alkene formation mechanisms. 2.3 Liquid phase tandem D/OM activity as a function of time and temperature Effects of temperature on n-eicosane conversion were investigated using a physical mixture of 1 % (g/g) Pd/γ-Al2O3 and 10 % (g/g) Re2O7/γ-Al2O3 at reaction temperatures of 190 °C, 200 °C, 210 °C, and 220 °C. We found C20 conversion increases with increasing reaction temperature, to a maximum of 68.8 ± 6.7 % conversion at 210 °C in 15 h but is lowered to 62.5 ± 5.6 % at 220 °C (Fig. 2 a). This maximum suggests there is a temperature induced deactivation mechanism for at least one of the two reactions in this tandem chemistry, which we propose is due to olefin metathesis active site deactivation. Supported Re2O7 olefin metathesis catalysts are generally thought to be catalytically active for olefin metathesis at room temperature [36] (25 °C) and up to 100 °C reaction temperatures, [37,38] which is well below the operating conditions presented here. Traditional, unpromoted Re-based olefin metathesis heterogeneous catalysts are known to suffer from relatively low overall turnover number (TON) as a result of deactivation, with a wealth of literature seeking to increase TON using promotors like boron [39] or tantalum oxide, [40] alkyl-metals (e.g., alkyl-tin), [41,42] and more, thoroughly summarized by Wachs et al. [43] or Coperet et al. [44]. To provide further insights into catalyst activity and stability over time we performed time-series reactions using sacrificial batch reactors harvested at different time points and online sampling of vapor-phase alkane self-metathesis using n-pentane. Fig. 2b and 2d show the change in conversion and product selectivity as a function of reaction duration. Reactions at 220 °C achieve an eicosane conversion of 36.5 ± 4.5 % in 2 h, after which activity rapidly declines, achieving an additional 25.9 % conversion in the remaining 13 h, resulting in a total conversion of 62.4 ± 5.6 % in 15 h. The 200 °C reaction shows activity that is 2.5-fold lower than 220 °C at 2 h, but remains active through 15 h, ending with an n-eicosane conversion of 64.8 ± 9.8 %, which is within error of the 220 °C performance. 2.4 Hydrogenolysis versus non-oxidative dehydrogenation reaction selectivity Pd-based catalysts are well-known to be active in alkane dehydrogenation, though, some have concluded that Pd is much less active than supported Pt. [45] As well, pure metallic Pd is known to exhibit poor reaction selectivity in alkane dehydrogenation which results in increased rates of hydrogenolysis [36] (i.e., C–C cleavage reactions), though these effects are typically seen while operating at disparate reaction conditions compared to our tandem system, with high exogenous partial pressures of H2 [36,38] with the alkane feed and reaction temperatures of 400 °C and above. [36–38] We sought to investigate whether the enhanced performance of the Pd-based catalyst compared to the Pt-based catalysts could be due to an alternative reaction pathway, like hydrogenolysis or cracking (Supporting Information Fig. S4). Cracking reaction pathways are generally thought to occur through higher barrier reaction pathways compared to alkane dehydrogenation, with one reaction product that is unique to hydrogenolysis, compared to alkane metathesis, methane. Appreciable quantities of methane cannot be produced through alkane metathesis, since the products are formed from exchange of functionalities across two alkenes, implying the smallest product that can be formed is ethane. We hypothesized that methane production was possible if the reactants went through a cracking or hydrogenolysis-type reaction pathway (Supporting Information Fig. S4). Headspace compositional analysis of our liquid phase reactors while performing alkane cross metathesis of 5 % n-eicosane in n-pentane for both 1 % Pd/γ-Al2O3 and 10 % Re2O7/γ-Al2O3, or 1 % Pt/γ-Al2O3 and 10 % Re2O7/γ-Al2O3 showed methane was present, however, at yields of 0.002 % and 0.007 % (mol/mol), respectively, compared to the starting n-eicosane in the reactor (Supporting Information Fig. S5, Fig. S6, and Table S5). Overall, gas phase hydrocarbon products (excluding the solvent vapor pressure) only accounted for < 2 % (g/g) of the starting n-eicosane loadings, when reactions were run at 200 or 220 °C (Supporting Information Table S5). Interestingly, methane was detected in the headspace of both the Pd-based and Pt-based reaction systems, with higher levels of methane detected in the Pt-based reactor. Thus, hydrogenolysis is occurring in our tandem system, which would result in higher populations of olefins (since H2 is being consumed) compared to an alkane metathesis system purely driven from non-oxidative dehydrogenation. Gas-phase studies below confirm the production of methane, again with Pt showing higher rates of production compared to Pd, with the admixture of Pt or Pd separate and upstream from Re2O7 resulting in the highest selectivity to methane and butane (Fig. 3 d), though at rates of formation that were over 10-fold less than physical mixtures (more below), again showing that Pt had higher selectivities toward hydrogenolysis products compared to Pd (see Pt/Re2O7 and Pd/Re2O7 in Fig. 3). Considering the similarities in the overall distribution of product selectivities in the liquid and gas-phase, we conclude that both the Pt and Pd catalysts are producing alkenes from alkanes using similar reaction schemes (i.e., a mixture of hydrogenolysis and non-oxidative dehydrogenation) and that increased Pd activity compared to Pt is not a result of an alternative alkene formation pathway. Product selectivities during gas-phase reactions further support this conclusion (Supporting Information Fig. S7), comparing Pt/Re2O7 and Pd/Re2O7 or PdxRe2O7, PtxRe2O7, and Pt3SnxRe2O7, showing nearly identical product selectivity distributions. Fig. 3a shows the rate of alkane formation and Fig. 3b shows the total alkane product formation over a period of approximately 7 h for vapor-phase alkane self-metathesis n-pentane (PC5 = 18.2 kPa) in a helium carrier gas using a physical mixture of 1 % Pd/γ-Al2O3 and 10 % Re2O7/γ-Al2O3 at 200°C. The time on stream data shows that the rate of alkane production decreases rapidly in the first 1.5 h. Power law regressions for the rate of formation of alkanes (Supporting Information Fig. S8) show that the Pt-based catalyst has more rapid deactivation compared to Pd, which is evident from the larger exponent of the power-law regressions. Power-law regressions have been established as a means to analyze catalyst deactivation rates for supported metal catalysts that are deactivated by coke deposits as far back as 1945. [46,47] More rapid deactivation for the Pt-based catalyst compared to the Pd can explain a portion of the difference in overall alkane metathesis performance, since rate of formation of accumulated reaction products decreases more rapidly for the Pt compared to the Pd catalyst over time. However, this more rapid deactivation cannot explain the entirety of the difference in reaction performance. We analyzed the Pt-based catalysts using the power law fit parameters from Pd (Supporting Information Fig. S8), to show if the Pt-based catalyst deactivated like the Pd-based catalysts, activity after 15-hours TOS would account for 33 % of the difference between Pd and Pt catalysts performance. In other words, 33 % of the difference in alkane formation rate between Pt and Pd at 15 hr, on a surface area basis, is due to differences in deactivation. Earlier work has identified that Re surface doping of Pd can reduce the rate of deactivation in hydrocarbon reactions, [38] suggesting elemental migration of the Re from the support to the surface of Pd-nanoparticles could provide a mechanism for reduced rates of deactivation. Elemental migration of Re is occurring in our system (more below), with scanning transmission electron microscopy – energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (STEM–EDS) showing that Pd and Re are within nanometer proximity, possibly co-locating Re on the surface of Pd nanoparticles. 2.5 Promotional effects from physical proximity of catalyst sites Previously, a more than two-fold increase in liquid-phase alkane metathesis activity [18] was identified from the combination of a physical mixture of alumina supported Sn1Pt1 and Re2O7 when pretreated in close physical proximity in air at 500 °C prior to reaction. This promotional effect coincided with a change in the physical proximity of the Sn1Pt1 and Re as seen from elemental migration measured by STEM-EDS. Here, we also saw elemental migration after catalyst pretreatment. Performing STEM-EDS on a physical mixture of 1 % Pd/γ-Al2O3 and 10 % Re2O7/γ-Al2O3 after pretreatment (Supporting Information Figs. S9–S12) and found that all γ-Al2O3 particles analyzed had both Pd and Re scattered throughout. The proximity of Pd and Re are within the resolution of the instrument, or 2 nm, since a trace analysis showed overlap of Pd and Re. Elemental mapping of the catalyst system without pretreatment showed the presence of Pd and Re on isolated γ-Al2O3 particles. To directly probe these proximity effects on reaction performance we used vapor-phase alkane metathesis of n-pentane in a custom-built reactor system (details in Supporting Information and Fig. S13), which allows for the direct measurement of the rate of formation for both alkane and alkene products while controlling catalyst proximity. Again, we saw promotional effects when the dehydrogenation and olefin metathesis catalysts were in nanometer-scale physical proximity during pretreatment (i.e., a physical mixture), though the level of promotion for Pd and Pt, in combination with Re2O7 were not the same. Since all gas-phase experiments shared the same loading of Re2O7, the rate of formation of alkanes or alkenes is shown as the specific rate, i.e., the rate of formation per surface area of dehydrogenation metal (rf''). We compared different packing geometries (i.e., admixtures) of the catalysts (Fig. 3c and Supporting Information Fig. S14), a physical mixture of 1 % Pd/γ-Al2O3 and 10 % Re2O7/γ-Al2O3 (PdxRe2O7), separate Pd and Re2O7 catalysts with Pd upstream of Re2O7 (Pd/Re2O7), a physical mixture of Pt and Re2O7 (PtxRe2O7), Pt upstream of Re2O7 (Pt/Re2O7) (Images of packing in Supporting Information Fig. S14), and a physical mixture of Pt3Sn and Re2O7 (Pt3SnxRe2O7). Analogous to the liquid phase results found in the alkane cross rearrangement of n-eicosane in n-pentane, the selectivity profile of reaction of n-pentane self-metathesis show nearly identical reaction selectivity distributions between PdxRe2O7, PtxRe2O7, and Pt3SnxRe2O7 further supporting the three catalysts are going through similar reaction pathways of alkane products. Additionally, the PdxRe2O7 showed the highest overall rate of formation of alkanes compared to PtxRe2O7 or Pt3SnxRe2O7, even when normalized to dehydrogenation metal surface area (all rates of alkane formation in Fig. 3 are specific to metal surface area of the dehydrogenation catalyst). The physical mixtures of PdxRe2O7 and PtxRe2O7 showed significantly higher rates of alkane formation compared to the physically separate systems, with the PdxRe2O7 showing a 42-fold increase in overall alkane formation rate compared to Pd/Re2O7 and the PtxRe2O7 showing an 18-fold increase compared with Pt/Re2O7. The overall rate of formation of alkenes (i.e., ethene, propene, butenes, hexenes, heptenes, and octenes) does show that Pd/Re2O7 provides the highest production of olefin-intermediates, compared to PtxRe2O7, Pt/Re2O7, PdxRe2O7, and Pt3SnxRe2O7. When Pd is in nanometer-scale proximity to ReOx, the rate of formation of alkenes is lowered by 60 %, while in the Pt system, separate or in nanometer-scale physical proximity to ReOx, alkene formation rates were within experimental error. This suggests that physical proximity of Pd and ReOx enhances hydrogenation rates, with decreasing rates of dehydrogenation (see in Fig. 3c). The same effect is not seen with Pt, where alkene formation rates remain constant while the rate of alkane formation rates increase, even though previous groups have seen that low concentration (∼ 70Pt: 1 Re) can enhance hydrogenation activity of benzene [48]. Rhenium doping of Pd nanoparticles has been identified as a unique promotor for increased hydrogenation activity, with groups showing how Re doping of Pd nanoparticles supported on alumina can increase selective hydrogenation activity by more than four-fold compared to Pd alone, by disrupting Pd ensembles [49,50], or in theoretical investigations that showed that C–H formation rates, through hydrogenation, can increase when Pd and ReOx are in close proximity due to more facile hydrogen transfer from Pd to the oxygenates on Re sites, and vice versa [51]. There have been numerous examples where supported or homogeneous Re-based catalysts, whether alone or as a dopant, have been shown to provide unique hydrogenation activity for a variety of reactions and functional groups, including alkenes, as highlighted by the recent review by Gothe et al. [52]. Investigations into the role of ReOx on supported catalysts can be difficult due to the mobility of ReOx species in oxidative treatments [53], like the conditions typically used in pretreating olefin metathesis catalysts [43], and the reducibility of ReOx species (depending on treatement and reaction conditions) resulting in distributions of oxidation states. Even so, we sought to directly probe this effect by synthesizing Re-doped (0.6 % and 1.9 %) 1 % Pd/γ-Al2O3 and compare these catalysts to PdxRe2O7 and Pd/Re2O7 (synthesis and experimental procedures described in the Supporting Information with results shown in Fig. S15). Interestingly, after doping the supported 1 % Pd/γ-Al2O3 with Re (either 0.6 % or 1.9 %) and re-reducing, the Re doped catalysts (Pd&Re/Re2O7) resulted in higher alkane formation rates when compared to the stacked Pd/Re2O7 system with rates that were 4.9x and 3.2x higher for the 1 % Pd doped with 0.6 % Re or 1.9 %, respectively. Interestingly, both catalyst systems had similar rates of alkene formation compared to the Pd/Re2O7. However, the total alkane formation rate for either of these systems remained over order of magnitude less active compared to the PdxRe2O7, showing that Re direct doping through incipient wetness impregnation does increase overall alkane formation, but the unique restructuring and possible isolation of specific oxidation states of Re from in situ pretreatments of PdxRe2O7 is challenging to recreate through direct synthesis. Regardless, co-locating ReOx in nano-scale proximity with Pd showed increased rates of hydrogenation and decreased rates of dehydrogenation, possibly from surface coverage effects that are difficult to directly synthesize, which resulted in overall Tandem D/OM activity differences when comparing Pt and Pd in tandem with supported Re2O7. 2.6 Orders in catalyst for tandem D/OM To further verify that dehydrogenation was the limiting the flux of products through alkane metathesis, we performed a series of reaction orders in catalyst studies (Fig. 4 ), for in Tandem D/OM. Reaction orders in catalyst provide insights into catalyst behavior and contributions in multi-step reaction sequences. Generally, first-order dependence in catalyst implies a linear correlation of reaction rate with the population of catalyst sites, while orders below or above one can imply unique deactivation mechanisms, dimeric active sites, or other mechanistic evidence of the role of each catalytic species [54,55]. All vapor-phase alkane metathesis reported rates are initial rates operating at differential conversion of n-pentane (< 10 %). Also, it is important to highlight, our analysis of alkenes is the sum of ethene, propene, butene, hexene, heptane, octene, and nonene, and not pentene, since our G.C. method & column were incapable of separating n-pentane and pentene. In other words, the kinetics of alkene formation requires the participation of olefin metathesis, thus the rate of formation of alkenes is measuring both dehydrogenation and olefin metathesis activity. We performed a series of reaction order in catalyst studies with physical mixtures of 10 % Re2O7/γ-Al2O3 and 1 % Pd/γ-Al2O3, in the liquid and vapor phase all at 200 °C. In all experiments, we measured near half-order dependence on Re2O7/γ-Al2O3, with vapor phase alkane self-metathesis of n-pentane giving a reaction order in Re of 0.4 ± 0.1 for the rate of formation of alkanes (Fig. 4b) and 0.4 ± 0.02 dependence in the formation of alkenes (Fig. 4c), or in the liquid-phase alkane cross metathesis of n-eicosane in n-pentane also showed 0.5 ± 0.1 order dependence on Re in the average rate of disappearance of C20 (Fig. 4a). Burés et al. recently showed how reaction orders in catalyst < 1, can arise from an off-reaction cycle inhibited state in equilibrium with the active species for homogeneous systems, where orders close to 0.5 is a sign that most of the sites are in their inactive form [56]. Maintaining heterogeneous olefin metathesis alkylidene active sites during reaction is an active area of research, and this technique could be highlighting an off-cycle inhibited state of the active site, which has been proposed in the field of heterogeneous olefin metathesis previously. For example, the Román group recently showed that a highly branched butene could be used to maintain the active form of W-based heterogeneous olefin metathesis active site, even showing that the presence of this promoter transitioned the reaction order in olefins (i.e., the reactant) to first-order from second-order behavior, and validating the proposed changed through a derived kinetic model. [57] More work is needed to fully understand the half-order dependence found here, especially as it relates to the bifunctional Re2O7 x Pd system, but the important conclusion for this work is that the rhenium active sites appear to be showing the same behavior across all reactions studied, including reactions in different phase and in tandem (i.e., alkane metathesis) or alone (i.e., olefin metathesis). Catalyst reaction orders in Pd showed first-order behavior for the rate of alkane formation in vapor phase n-pentane self-metathesis (1.2 ± 0.2) (Fig. 4b) and in the average rate of alkane disappearance in the alkane cross metathesis of 5 % (g/g) n-eicosane in n-pentane in the liquid-phase (0.9 ± 0.1) (Fig. 4a, product selectivity distributions found in Supporting Information Fig. S17 and Fig. S18). However, catalyst order dependence for Pd in alkene formation was −0.2 ± 0.1 (Fig. 4c). In other words, additional Pd catalyst resulted in slight reductions in the rate of formation for alkenes, while simultaneously resulting in significant increases in the rate of formation of alkanes (Pd order dependence in alkane formation was 1.2 ± 0.2) meaning additional Pd catalyst provided increased rates of hydrogenation, which reduced the overall rate of alkene formation and significantly increased the rate of alkane formation. Fig. 3c, supports this conclusion, with the overall rate of alkene formation decreasing by 60 % (i.e., higher rates of hydrogenation) when the Pd and Re2O7 active sites are in nanometer-scale physical proximity. The overall outcome of nanometer-scale proximity is drastically higher rates of alkane formation with lower measurable rates of alkene formation. This phenomenon appears to be unique to Pd, since the rate of formation of alkenes for Pt, whether in nanometer-scale physical proximity (PtxRe2O7) or separate (Pt/Re2O7), were within error of one another (Fig. 3c), and on a surface area basis was within error of the physically mixed Pt3Sn (Pt3SnxRe2O7), as well. We expect the concentration of hydrogen in our system to be extremely low, based on estimated alkane dehydrogenation conversion of pentane to pentene and H2 at these conditions (PH2 ∼ 0.4 kPa, Supporting Information Fig. S16). However, hydrogenolysis activity would lower H2 concentrations and increase concentrations of equilibrium limited alkenes. We did measure hydrogenolysis activity with both Pt/Re2O7 and Pd/Re2O7 system, but methane production was below the limits of detection for the PdxRe2O7 system after the first G.C. injection. All together, we postulate that accessibility to hydrogen at these conditions is resulting in differences in the overall rate of formation of alkanes. Hydrogen surface coverage will differ between Pt and Pd, due to differences in H adsorption energies [58], with metals that have stronger adsorption energies having high H coverage, resulting in a hydrogen-rich surface that would favor hydrogenation and reduce dehydrogenation rates. Metals with weak H-binding energy would have lower surface concentrations of H adatoms and higher rates of desorption of H2 into the bulk volume of the reactor, with previous groups seeing similar effects between Pd and Pt [59] or when doping Ir into Pd [60]. Palladium strongly adsorbs and even can absorb H atoms, depending on conditions [61,62], where recent theoretical analyses show enthalpies of absorption that are exothermic (∼0.18 eV), even at the conditions operated here, [61] while predictions for bulk metal or nanoparticle hydrogen absorption by Pt are endothermic by ∼ 0.3 eV. [63] This explains how the higher rate of formation of alkanes could come from differences in H surface coverage resulting in increased hydrogenation activity for the PdxRe2O7 as compared to PtxRe2O7. Thus, overall Tandem D/OM activity is governed by the many identified structure–property relationships known in alkane dehydrogenation (i.e., metal identity, nanoparticle size, etc.), but differences in H-coverage, deriving from stronger H adsorption energies result in differences in hydrogenation activity that govern overall Tandem D/OM activity when comparing elements with the highest olefin formation rates, like Pt and Pd. 2.7 Reaction performance applied to polyethylene feedstocks Using the Pd-based dehydrogenation catalyst with Re2O7/γ-Al2O3 we saw increased conversion of PE depolymerization in n-pentane requiring 33 % less catalyst for increased PE loadings (i.e., 250 % higher), compared to a Pt1Sn1/γ-Al2O3 catalyst [18], while operating at a lower reaction temperature of 190 °C for the same reaction duration 15 h. Fig. 5 shows the molecular weight distribution of the extracted residual solids using high-temperature gel permeation chromatography (a), where all solids recovered in a reactor, including solids that were splashed onto the walls and head of the reactor (mostly unreacted), after decanting reaction liquids and allowing the solids to dry at ambient temperature overnight. The polymer control was also put through the same procedure, by placing the polymer in a reactor with n-pentane solvent and heated to 190 °C for 15 h. Again, the liquids were decanted, and solids dried overnight at ambient temperature. Polymers were then extracted from the recovered solids using 1,2,4-trichlorobenzene (details found in Materials & Methods). For the ratios of PE:C5 of 1.0, 1.5, and 2.5 % (g/g) shown in Fig. 5 had average molecular weights lowered by 94.9 %, 90.8 %, and 92.1 %, respectively, including the polymer scrapped from the upper walls and head of the reactor. The recovered liquid phase products (b and c), as a function of polymer loading using a physical mixture of 500 mg of 1 % Pd/γ-Al2O3 and 10 % Re2O7/γ-Al2O3 reacted at 190 °C for 15 h. The total recovered liquid-phase products (C3 − C35) were consistent at all PE: C5 ratios, suggesting the turn-over number in each reactor is consistent at the same catalyst loadings. The result is evident from the HT-GPC traces showing increases in the molecular weight of products with increasing PE loading (Supporting Information Fig. S18). It is important to note, our GC analysis for liquid phase products stopped at C35 (Mw = 497 g/mol), thus the GPC trace shows larger oligomers (Mw between 500 and 1,100 g/mol) that have drastically lower molecular weights than the starting polymer but are technically missing in our recovered products due to instrument limitations. Reactions with a higher molecular weight feedstock (125 kDa) did show conversion with number after molecular weight lowering by over 95 % (and yield of products), though, HT-GPC results showed that the highest molecular weight fragments (> 100,000 g/mol) of the feedstock appear to be unreacted, even possibly having increases in molecular weight. This was evident from the HT-GPC trace and post reaction solids which showed small granules of polymer that appeared to never solubilize (Supporting Information Fig. S20d), which was not the case with the 54 ± 2 kDa feedstock. We hypothesize this insolubility is due to lower-critical solution temperature behavior for polyethylene and n-pentane mixtures, which has been thoroughly characterized previously, where polymer insolubility can increase above a certain temperature, molecular weight, or reduced pressure, until a measurable second, polymer-rich, phase appears. [64,65] Our studies are operating in a regime of polyethylene melting and solvation, at least for the 54 ± 2 kDa feedstock, while the 125 kDa feedstock may have polymer chains that never fully solubilize residing in a melted polymer rich-phase instead, as opposed to a homogeneous solution. The result is poor conversion of the higher molecular weight polymers, with residual polymer granules recovered after reaction (Supporting Information Fig. S20). We also explored the impact of dehydrogenation catalyst on polymer conversion and product yield, identifying similar trends as with model compounds showing surprisingly high activity for a 0.8 % Pd/γ-Al2O3 compared to the 1 % Pdγ-Al2O3, which we attribute to nanoparticle size effects (Supporting Information Figs. S20–S22). 3 Conclusions In this study we demonstrated that a tandem heterogeneous catalyst system of a wide variety of dehydrogenation catalysts in combination with a Re2O7/γ-Al2O3 olefin metathesis catalyst is capable of alkane rearrangement of n-eicosane in n-pentane, polyethylene in n-pentane, or gas-phase n-pentane self-rearrangement, each yielding a distribution of linear alkane products at temperatures below 220 °C. We show that alkane dehydrogenation activity relationships generally translate to alkane metathesis activity, when comparing Pt, Pt3Sn, Pd, Ru, Co, and Ni, though differences between Pt and Pd-based systems appear more complex. We propose differences between Pd and Pt are due to differences in hydrogenation derived from differences in H surface coverage. By exploring catalyst activity and reaction kinetics for a diverse set of reactants, we show Pd provides for superior activity compared to Pt due to reduced rates of deactivation, but mostly due to enhanced rates of hydrogenation found from Pd nanoparticles patterned with ReOx. When we applied these catalyst systems to the alkane metathesis of a polyethylene feedstock, PdxRe2O7 showed exceptional activity, with 94.9 % reduction in molecular weight of the polymer feedstock at 190 °C for 15 h. We believe further investigations into alkane metathesis of polyolefin polymers should focus on using inexpensive alkane co-reactants (i.e., ethane, propane, or butane), since certain hydrocarbon feedstocks may be cheaper than green hydrogen on a mole basis, while providing for similar distributions of products when comparing to hydrogenolysis or hydrocracking to naphtha range products. coredata.dc:description: Recent proposed approaches in the depolymerization of waste plastics employ an olefin intermediate to produce alkanes or alkenes using olefin metathesis in tandem chemistry. Here we investigated the role of the dehydrogenation catalyst on reaction rate, kinetics, and product distribution in heterogeneous tandem dehydrogenation and olefin metathesis (alkane metathesis) of three different alkane reactants, including polyethylene. We found that many properties to which alkane dehydrogenation rates were sensitive—including metal composition, nanoparticle size, and surface doping of Re species also controlled activity in Tandem D/OM. When comparing Pd, Pt, and Pt3Sn1, supported Pd in tandem with a Re2O7 olefin metathesis catalyst showed four-fold higher activity (surface area basis) compared to Pt or Pt3Sn1 catalysts on the same support, mainly due to differences in the rate of hydrogenation. Catalyst preparation resulted in metal nanoparticles partially covered by ReOx, as seen from elemental mapping. Co-location of Re2O7 and Pd correlated with increased rates of hydrogenation (i.e., an increase in the rate of alkane formation and simultaneous lowering of the rate of alkene formation), with a reaction order in catalyst study that further supported this conclusion. The Pd and Re2O7 system displayed marked improvement compared to Pt or Pt3Sn1 with Re2O7, and previous work, in the depolymerization rate of a linear polyethylene feedstock, with over 94 % reduction in polymer molecular weight in 15 h at 190 °C using less catalyst and increased reactant loadings, while keeping solvent to polymer consumption below 2.5.
